meanings.definition: To tie or fasten something tightly
meanings.sent1: I need to bind the papers together with a rubber band.
meanings.sent2: She used a rope to bind the boxes securely.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy tried to bind its tail to the chair with a ribbon.
meanings.sent4: The magical spell seemed to bind the two objects together.
meanings.sent5: The strong adhesive can bind the pieces instantly.

meanings.definition: To form a close relationship or connection
meanings.sent1: Their shared love for music helped bind them as friends.
meanings.sent2: The experience of traveling together can bind people closely.
meanings.sent3: The funny incident at the party seemed to bind them even more.
meanings.sent4: Music has the power to bind hearts across cultures.
meanings.sent5: The heartfelt conversation helped bind their friendship forever.

meanings.definition: To make a formal agreement or commitment
meanings.sent1: They will bind the contract with their signatures.
meanings.sent2: The handshake was a way to bind their business deal.
meanings.sent3: The ancient ritual was used to bind the two kingdoms in peace.
meanings.sent4: The legal document will bind them to their promises.
meanings.sent5: The oath taken will bind them to their duties.

meanings.definition: To cause someone to feel restricted or obligated
meanings.sent1: The strict rules can bind employees to follow certain procedures.
meanings.sent2: The heavy workload can bind workers to long hours.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected favor might bind him to return the kindness.
meanings.sent4: The sense of duty can bind individuals to their responsibilities.
meanings.sent5: The promise made will bind her to keep her word.
